while this video is an excellent tool for teaching the simplified version of complexity, evolution doesn't always favour complex things. ctenophores, who are triploblasts (some are diploblasts too though), with a mouth and two anuses, came after sponges, as basal eumetazoans, and developed neurones independently (and before) the neurones we think of (and with) today. next up is placozoa, who are directly related to cnidaria, as a sister group. these are their older twins, essentially. acoels + xenoturbella are the simplest bilaterians, and platyhelminthes are descended from slightly more complex spiralian protostome ancestors, with gastrotricha being their closest relative. they're the platyzoa. gastrotrichs are pseudocoelomate, but many are also acoelomates just like platyhelminthes. i'm sure you guys at scishow already know that, but i just wanted to tell anybody that didn't know.

You are trying to say that unrelated - consecutive - complementary - accidental changes or "mutations" account for the millions of uniform symmetrical differences of every genus there is. You need to understand that there is an immune system and homeostasis that resists those kinds of changes, which never really happen, to begin with. A single beneficial mutation, entirely free of side effects is extremely rare while multiple beneficial changes that are complementary to previous changes and the rest of the entire genome are entirely out of the question, especially when you need millions or even billions of such changes for evolution to ever occur, which is a mathematical absurdity.

The only real defence for octopii is in the terms of general use (a lot of words that end -us in english are often pluralised as -ii), however that argument fails since the obvious pluralisation is octopuses, and that the "-ii" pluralisation for even latin root words is archaic.   So if you really want to use a pretentious pluralisation, octopodes. If you want to use the pluralisation that will get your point across as clearly as possible (which is really the function of language) - octopuses.

On pluralisation of octopus, if you are following the ideal that words that borrowed words should have the plural of the donor language (so "genius" from latin, becomes "genii"), then the plural of octopus is octopodes, however if you are following the idea that borrowed words should take the pluralisation of the adopting language (so "genius" would become "geniuses"), then octopus becomes octopuses.

Many words in the English language are borrowed words from Latin or Greek, so they keep the original pluralization. This is how cactus & octopus ->  cacti & octopi, flagella & antenna -> flagellae & antennae, crisis & thesis -> crises & theses, and bacterium & phenomenon -> bacteria & phenomena. This has been changing slightly though, because people don't speak or learn Ancient Greek & Latin anymore. Therefore, octopuses is also correct, because it's so commonly used that it's been anglicized.

The latin 'octopus', which is used in taxonomy, also is a third declention word, its nominative plural also is 'octopodes'. 'Octopi' is hypercorrect, mistaking 'octopus' for an o-declension word, and therefore wrong.

Dude. Latin has 5 declentions. Words like radius, servus, hortus, etc. are the o-declension, they indeed end in -i in nominative plural. Other words like manus, senatus, porticus, magistratus are the u-declension, their nomative plural too ends in -us. 'Octopus' is the latinized version of the greek word 'ὀκτώπους' (octopous – meaning eight-foot, its greek third declention nominative plural being ὀκτώπόδες/octopodes).

Um, actually octopi is a legitimate English word that is used as the plural of octopus in addition to octopuses, which is most correct. It is certainly more correct than octopodes which is Greek not English. This is because whilst the word is derived from Greek it is being used as an English word. This is similar to how words like "beef" were adapted from French.

It's neither Greek nor Latin, but a word derived from both. It is an English word now, so the plural is used in the English context as opposed to the original Greek context, thus making him more correct in these circumstances.
